A Statistical View of DB â–ª So far, we have been taking a logic-based view on DB â€“ A DB instance forms an interpretation of some logic system. â–ª In this lecture, we are going to take a more statistical view â€“ A DB instance contains a set of samples of the history, what can we learn about the future? âž¢ Data Mining âž¢ In-DB Machine Learning â–ª It is a huge area on its own, in this lecture we will scratch the surface and walk through how to use some off-the-shelf tools. â–ª The goal of this lecture is NOT to teach you machine learning â€“ the goal is to introduce basic concepts and focus on showing you that you can do all these in a DB. extract information from data â–ª They try to find information provided by groups of data (itemsets, clusters, nearest neighbors, etc.) â–ª An intermediate step between those more ML algorithms and conventional query processing are data cubes â–ª Data cubes are part of analytical databases, are manipulated through extensions of SQL (and other languages), and are widely used in a wide range of applications as the source of data for reports or for further analysis An example of a data cube Dimensions: Region, product, day Fact: Sales Region Day Product Sales R1 D2 P3 105000 R2 D1 P2 27000 R2 D3 P4 43500 CUBE SELECT Country, Region, SUM(Sales) AS TotalSales FROM Sales GROUP BY CUBE (Country, Region); https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/t-sql/queries/select-group-by- transact-sql?view=sql-server-ver16 The CUBE operator â–ª The CUBE operator performs several aggregations: SELECT A, B, AGGREGATE(C) FROM table_name GROUP BY CUBE (A , B); â–ª For all combinations (A,B) â–ª For all values of A â–ª For all values of B â–ª The total â–ª The set of aggregations performed is 2n with n the number of columns involved â–ª For 3 attributes: (A,B,C), (A,B), (A,C), (B,C), (A), (B), (C), total ROLLUP SELECT Country, Region, SUM(Sales) AS TotalSales FROM Sales GROUP BY ROLLUP (Country, Region);
